supra-auricular scales: distinctive spinelike supra-auricular scales in subadults and adults
temporals: the lower two contacting the postoculars
superciliary: similar in length to other scales in series
subocular: which is the posteriormost scale in this series to reach the orbit
preauriculars: at least three rows of granular preauriculars
infralabials: often about twice as long as preceding infralabials
dorsal longitudinal scale rows: 14 dorsal longitudinal scale rows arranged parallel to ventrolateral fold
body color: adults dark green or dark blue-green

supra-auricular scales: distinctive spinelike supra-auricular scales in subadults and adults
juvenile pattern: juvenile pattern of dark dorsal crossbands
anterior superciliary: similar in length to other scales in series
posterior subocular: which is the posteriormost scale in this series to reach the orbit
posteriormost infralabial: often about twice as long as preceding infralabials
longitudinal nuchal scale rows: usually six longitudinal nuchal scale rows
dorsal coloration: adult greenish dorsal coloration with much black mottling concentrated into indistinct dorsal crossbands

supranasals: supranasals not expanded and not in contact at dorsal midline
temporals: three anterior temporals in each side
temporal scales: fifth row of temporal scales absent
frontonasal: frontonasal usually in contact with frontal
head scales: posterior head scales weakly developed knob-like
supercilliary: anterior supercilliary not contacting the cantholoreal
suboccular: posterior suboccular separated from the lower primary temporal by the penultimate scale in the supralabial series
temporal: lower anterior temporal in broad contact with antepenultimate supralabial

supra-auricular scales: distinctive spinelike supra-auricular scales in subadults and adults
internasals: posterior internasals relatively large through fusion with canthals
canthals: these apparently fused with posterior internasals
superciliary: similar in length to other scales in series
subocular: which is the posteriormost scale in this series to reach the orbit
dorsal longitudinal scale rows: 14 dorsal longitudinal scale rows arranged parallel to ventrolateral fold
juvenile pattern: juvenile pattern of a broad pale brown middorsal stripe
parietals: parietals usually in contact with the median supraoculars
crossbands: subadults and young adults with brown chevron-shaped crossbands

supra-auricular scales: supra-auricular scales of subadults and adults spinelike
posterior subocular: posterior subocular broadly separated from the lower primary temporal by the penultimate supralabial
preauricular scales: two or occasionally three incomplete rows of subimbricate preauricular scales
dorsal midline contact: not in contact at the dorsal midline
anterior internasals: only slightly larger than the anterior internasals
anterior temporals: three or four anterior temporals per side
parietal contact: parietal not in contact with median supraoculars
scale length: similar in length to other scales in series
orbit: the posteriormost scale in this series to reach the orbit
juvenile color: juveniles and subadults with dark brown crossbands

supra-auricular scales: distinctive spinelike supra-auricular scales in adults
supraocular contact: narrow parietal-median supraocular contact on one side
subocular: posterior subocular broadly separated from the lower primary temporal
dorsal longitudinal scale rows: 14 dorsal longitudinal scale rows arranged parallel to ventrolateral fold

supranasals: but not contacting each other at the dorsal midline
superciliary: longer than other scales in series
subocular: the posteriormost scale in this series to reach the orbit
preauricular scales: Two rows of subimbricate to granular preauricular scales

subocular: the posteriormost scale in this series to reach the orbit
infralabials: usually about twice as long as preceding infralabials
preauricular scales: granular preauricular scales in about three rows
parietal: lower two contacting postoculars and upper scale relatively small and variably in contact with parietal
head scales: posterior head scales of adults not strongly convex or knoblike
dorsal midline: not in contact at dorsal midline
temporal scale: the upper temporal scale intervenes to partially or completely separate the parietal from the median supraocular series
scales in series: similar in length to other scales in series
nuchal scales: longitudinal nuchal scales in six rows
longitudinal scale rows: arranged parallel relative to ventrolateral fold
dorsum: dorsum of adults green or cream-colored with heavy black mottling
subadults: subadults bronze with black spots arranged in irregular transverse series across dorsum

supra-auricular scales: distinctive spinelike supra-auricular scales in subadults and adults
superciliary: anterior superciliary contacting cantholoreal or not
subocular: the posteriormost scale in this series to reach the orbit
dorsal longitudinal scale rows: 14 dorsal longitudinal scale rows arranged parallel to ventrolateral fold
juvenile pattern: juvenile pattern with a broad pale brown middorsal stripe

temporals: upper temporals small and pointed whereas the lower temporals are large and smooth
subocular: subocular with a distinct keel located between the fourth and fifth upper labials and not contacting the lip
dorsal scales: dorsal scales are pointed and smooth
dorsal colour pattern: adult males have intricate colouration of black reticulation that covers most of the dorsal area and the rows of pale ocelli become indistinct or may completely disappear
colouration: sub-adults have reddish or white ventral tail colour

head shape: head not or only scarcely distinct from neck
eye shape: with round or vertically subelliptical pupil
loreal shape: the loreal extending from the nasal to the eye

colouration: intricate network of dark markings connected with one another but isolate spots of the brown or tawny ground colour
nasal bones: nasal bones fused anteriorly to form pointed median anterior process
coronoid process: compound bone of lower jaw without coronoid process
dentary teeth: posterior dentary teeth resembling other teeth in form
scales of lips: between eye and edge of lip
scale behind nasal: no transversely enlarged scale behind nasal
cloacal region: the arms of the U directed backward as a pair of pockets into which anal glands open
palatine-pterygoid teeth: palatine-pterygoid teeth gradually diminishing in length from before backward
nasals and septomaxillae: nasals and septomaxillae not in contact with frontal
frontal-prefrontal contact: frontal-prefrontal contact confined to region dorsal to lachrymal foramen

overall pattern: overall either patternless or with bars or longitudinal lines

head scales: head scales generally normal for colubrids
dorsal scales: and slightly notched posteriorly without apical pits
tail length: of total length in adult males
frontal bones: combined frontal bones nearly one-third again as long as they are broad
prefrontal: prefrontal as long as it is high

ventral scales: center and posterior edge of ventral scales corn yellow overlaid with buff
supralabials: 4th and 5th supralabials of nearly equal size
dorsal pattern: dorsal pattern with 1 pale stripe and 4 dark stripes on a grayish brown or olive brown ground color
vertebral row: vertebral row gray with yellow pigment at anterior end of each scale

frontoparietal and parietal plates: frontoparietal and parietal plates in contact with interparietals
scales between supraoculars and supracil: usually in single row between supraoculars and supraciliaries
occipitals: usually subequal to first dorsal row
posterior gulars: 16 posterior gulars between antegular and gular folds
mesoptychial scales: enlarged mesoptychial scales subequal or larger than largest gulars
scales between interparietals and base o: 339 scales between interparietals and base of tail

head shape: head moderately distinct from the neck
ventral color: venter pale ochre-brown or pale brown on a wide central area
keeling: barely or weakly keeled at midbody and on the posterior part of the body
ventral edging: broadly edged with dark brown or blackish on the outer quarter of ventrals
ventral darkness: rarely entirely dark except on its most anterior part
dorsal spots: dorsum usually scattered with blackish-brown or black spots or blotches
neck streak: pale yellowish-brown streak on the sides of the neck before the dorsolateral stripe
nape streak: plus a streak on the nape behind the parietals

contact: first pair in contact with each other
chin shields: fifth infralabials in contact with anterior chin shields
reduced scale rows: dorsal scale rows reduced from 19 to 17 at position of third and fourth dorsal scale rows and from 81st to 86th ventrals
lateral line: formed by outer edges of ventral shields

ventrolateral stripe: producing a very irregular ventrolateral stripe
dorsal color: dark reddish-brown or probably dark chestnut-brown in life
postocular streak: blackish-brown postocular streak extending from behind the eye to the corner of the mouth
preservative color: more or less dark greyish-brown or dark yellowish-grey in preservative
edging: narrowly edged on its both sides with dark brown or black
extension: 7th dorsal scale rows from the occipital region along the whole of the body
dorsal edging: many dorsal scales longitudinally edged with dark brown
reticulation: producing a faint reticulation or irregular streaks
blackish-brown edging: upper edge of scales of the 1st dorsal scale row and lower edge of those of 2nd row blackish-brown
gap: usually separated by a wide gap from the dark line edging the lower side of the dorsolateral stripe
chevron: no chevron on the upper part of the neck
ventral tips: with the outer edge of ventral tips blackish-brown
diastema: the last two moderately enlarged and separated from anterior teeth by a distinct diastema
1st dorsal row: smooth or at best feebly keeled 1st dorsal row

infralabials: mostly edged with black at their posterior border
dorsal scales: all weekly keeled or smooth at outmost one or two rows
body stripe: single white to orange stripe extended from angulus oris to neck
dorsal body: with or without single series of white spots or short band on lateral
head: head moderately distinct from neck

head shape: head moderately distinct from the neck
postocular streak: a dark postocular streak usually present
sexual dimorphism: length of the portion of tail with 4 dorsal scale rows
keeled scales: scales around the base of the tail strongly keeled
neck pattern: and an ochre-yellow or yellowish-brown streak on each side of the neck and nape forming an incomplete collar
